ai-ps2.6:1.2_0: At one time the Fortunate One was dwelling near Bārāṇasī in the Deer Park at Isipatana.
ai-ps2.6:1.3_0: There the Buddha addressed the group of five:
ai-ps2.6:2.1_0: “There are these two opposites that should not be pursued by one who has gone forth.
ai-ps2.6:2.3_0: Indulgence in sensual pleasures, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless.
ai-ps2.6:2.4_0: * Now, that which is painful, ignoble, and pointless,
ai-ps2.6:2.5_0: By avoiding both these opposites, I have awakened to the middle path, which produces vision and knowledge, which leads to peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-ps2.6:3.1_0: And what is that middle way of practice?
ai-ps2.6:3.2_0: It’s just this noble eightfold path,
ai-ps2.6:3.4_0: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-ps2.6:4.1_0: Now this, monks, is the noble truth of suffering:
ai-ps2.6:4.2_0: birth is suffering, old age is suffering, sickness is suffering, death is suffering, association with what is disliked is suffering, separation from what is liked is suffering, not getting what one wants is suffering.
ai-ps2.6:4.3_0: in brief, the five constituents (of mind and body) that provide fuel for attachment are suffering.
ai-ps2.6:4.4_0: Now this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.
ai-ps2.6:4.5_0: the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is,
ai-ps2.6:4.6_0: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.
ai-ps2.6:4.7_0: Now this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
ai-ps2.6:4.8_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-ps2.6:4.9_0: Now this is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-ps2.6:4.10_0: It’s just this noble eightfold path,
ai-ps2.6:5.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of suffering.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-ps2.6:5.2_0: ‘This noble truth of suffering should be completely understood.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-ps2.6:5.3_0: When I knew that this was the, vision arose in me, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, and light arose, in regard to things not heard before.
ai-ps2.6:6.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-ps2.6:6.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-ps2.6:6.3_0: When I had been given up, vision arose in me, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, and light arose, in regard to things not heard before.
ai-ps2.6:7.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-ps2.6:7.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-ps2.6:7.3_0: vision arose in me, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, and light arose, in regard to things not heard before.
ai-ps2.6:8.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-ps2.6:8.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.’ Such was the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. ...
ai-ps2.6:8.3_0: When I was developed, vision arose in me, knowledge arose, wisdom arose, understanding arose, and light arose, in regard to things not heard before.
ai-ps2.6:9.1_0: As long as my true knowledge and vision about these four noble truths was not fully purified in these three perspectives and twelve respects, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-ps2.6:10.1_0: But when my true knowledge and vision about these four noble truths was fully purified in these three perspectives and twelve respects, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-ps2.6:10.2_0: And knowledge and vision arose in me:
ai-ps2.6:10.3_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
ai-ps2.6:11.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-ps2.6:11.2_0: Satisfied, the group of five mendicants was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-ps2.6:12.1_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, Venerable Koṇḍañña experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
ai-ps2.6:12.2_0: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-ps2.6:13.1_0: When the Buddha had set rolling the wheel of the Teaching, the earth gods cried out,
ai-ps2.6:13.2_0: “Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
